scene_title: Introduction: The NAMCS Health Center Ecosystem
narrative_purpose: Set the context by introducing the key players, concepts, and relationships in the NAMCS HC Component ecosystem. Show how FQHCs, NCHS, HRSA, and PCOR are interconnected.

nodes.label: NAMCS HC Component
nodes.description: Redesigned survey collecting EHR visit data from health centers since 2021

nodes.label: FQHCs
nodes.description: Federally Qualified Health Centers serving 31.3 million patients

nodes.label: FQHC Look-alikes
nodes.description: Health centers meeting HRSA requirements without Program funding

nodes.label: NCHS
nodes.description: National Center for Health Statistics - conducts the survey

nodes.label: HRSA
nodes.description: Health Resources and Services Administration - oversees Health Center Program

nodes.label: HUD
nodes.description: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development - external linkage partner

nodes.label: EHR Data
nodes.description: Electronic Health Records submitted by participating centers

nodes.label: Uniform Data System
nodes.description: HRSA reporting system for health center characteristics

nodes.label: Health Professional Shortage Areas
nodes.description: Underserved areas where FQHCs provide critical healthcare

nodes.label: Researchers
nodes.description: Users of datafiles and dashboards for healthcare research

nodes.label: Patients
nodes.description: 67.3% in poverty, served by health centers

nodes.label: Policymakers
nodes.description: Use data for evidence-based decision making

nodes.label: Datafiles
nodes.description: Restricted and public use datasets for research

narrative_text: The NAMCS Health Center Component represents a comprehensive ecosystem connecting federal agencies, healthcare providers, and research communities. At its core, the NCHS-administered survey collects electronic health record data from Federally Qualified Health Centers and their look-alikesâ€”community-based settings that serve 31.3 million patients in health professional shortage areas. This data flows into research products including datafiles and interactive dashboards, enabling patient-centered outcomes research that benefits patients, researchers, and policymakers alike. External linkages to agencies like HUD expand the analytical possibilities, creating a powerful infrastructure for understanding healthcare delivery to underserved populations.
